citations.narrative:
Two young adult standard poodles did not have adequate shelter in their outdoor enclosure. The poodles had access to 2
shelter structures but one shelter was a medium igloo that could not fit both dogs at once and would limit the normal
postural adjustments of a single dog. The second shelter structure was a small lean-to with only a roof and 3 walls; it
lacked a floor, a fourth wall, and a wind break. Adequate shelter is important for dogs to stay warm and dry and escape
inclement weather. All outdoor-housed dogs must have access to a shelter with a roof, 4 walls, and a floor, and is large
enough for each dog to make normal postural adjustments. The shelter must also have a wind break at the entrance and
contain clean, dry bedding if the temperature is below 50 degrees. Correct by 2/8/25 by ensuring all outdoor housed dogs
have adequate shelters that meet the regulations.

Fourteen dogs did not have water at the time of inspection. All 14 dogs were juvenile/young adult French Bulldogs that the
licensee stated liked to play with/dump their water bowls. The licensee stated she currently provides fresh water in the
mornings and evenings. At approximately 12pm, these dogs had not yet received water that morning. The licensee
provided water and while the dogs did lap at the water when provided, they were easily distracted away from the water.
Water is vital to life. Dogs without continual access to water may have difficulty maintaining hydration, regulating their
body temperature, and can experience distress from thirst. Potable water must be continuously available to dogs at all
times. Correct by 2/8/25

The licensee was not able to provide an appropriate program of vet care in writing during the inspection. A written vaccine
and deworming schedule for puppies was reviewed but it was not signed by the veterinarian. No vaccine or deworming
schedule, sampling frequency for heartworms or intestinal parasites, or preventative care guidelines for adult dogs was
provided. It is important to have a program of vet care in writing to ensure that the licensee is providing appropriate
preventative care to their dogs under the direction of their attending veterinarian. Correct by 3/1/25 by developing and
documenting in writing with signature by the veterinarian, a program of vet care that addresses regularly scheduled visits
by the vet and physical exams of all dogs at least every 12 months, vaccinations of all dogs and sampling for parasites,
and preventative care for healthy haircoats, nails, eyes, ears, skin, and teeth.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.4(b) 
   
Outdoor housing facilities. 
Two young adult standard poodles did not have adequate shelter in their outdoor enclosure. The poodles had access to 2 
shelter structures but one shelter was a medium igloo that could not fit both dogs at once and would limit the normal 
postural adjustments of a single dog. The second shelter structure was a small lean-to with only a roof and 3 walls; it 
lacked a floor, a fourth wall, and a wind break. Adequate shelter is important for dogs to stay warm and dry and escape 
inclement weather. All outdoor-housed dogs must have access to a shelter with a roof, 4 walls, and a floor, and is large 
enough for each dog to make normal postural adjustments. The shelter must also have a wind break at the entrance and 
contain clean, dry bedding if the temperature is below 50 degrees. Correct by 2/8/25 by ensuring all outdoor housed dogs 
have adequate shelters that meet the regulations. 
3.10(a) 
   
Watering 
Fourteen dogs did not have water at the time of inspection. All 14 dogs were juvenile/young adult French Bulldogs that the 
licensee stated liked to play with/dump their water bowls. The licensee stated she currently provides fresh water in the 
mornings and evenings. At approximately 12pm, these dogs had not yet received water that morning. The licensee 
provided water and while the dogs did lap at the water when provided, they were easily distracted away from the water. 
Water is vital to life. Dogs without continual access to water may have difficulty maintaining hydration, regulating their 
body temperature, and can experience distress from thirst. Potable water must be continuously available to dogs at all 
times. Correct by 2/8/25 
3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee was not able to provide an appropriate program of vet care in writing during the inspection. A written vaccine 
and deworming schedule for puppies was reviewed but it was not signed by the veterinarian. No vaccine or deworming 
schedule, sampling frequency for heartworms or intestinal parasites, or preventative care guidelines for adult dogs was 
provided. It is important to have a program of vet care in writing to ensure that the licensee is providing appropriate 
preventative care to their dogs under the direction of their attending veterinarian. Correct by 3/1/25 by developing and 
documenting in writing with signature by the veterinarian, a program of vet care that addresses regularly scheduled visits

by the vet and physical exams of all dogs at least every 12 months, vaccinations of all dogs and sampling for parasites, 
and preventative care for healthy haircoats, nails, eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
 n
